trial_identification.studytitle: Maintenance Transcranial Electrical Stimulation for Depression
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A Study of Transcranial Electrical Stimulation (TES) as a Maintenance Treatment for Depression

interventions.interventions:
Treatment: devices - Transcranial electrical stimulation
Experimental: Transcranial electrical stimulation -
Treatment: devices: Transcranial electrical stimulation

primaryOutcome.outcome: Montgomery Asberg Depression Rating Scale for Depression (MADRS)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
- All participants will be = 18 years old.
- Participants must have experienced a significant clinical response, defined as = 50% decrease from baseline scores on the Montgomery Asberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS).
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
- Inadequate response to acute trial of TES.
- Suicidality.
- Clinically defined neurological disorder or insult.
- Metal in the cranium, skull defects, or skin lesions on scalp (cuts, abrasions, rash) at proposed electrode sites.
- Pregnancy (women of childbearing age will be asked to undergo a urine pregnancy test prior to starting the study).
- Concurrent long acting benzodiazepines, ritalin or dexamphetamine medication.
- Treatment for depression is changed during months 3-9 of the trial.

recruitment.hospital: Black Dog Institute / University of New South Wales - Randwick, Sydney

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: The University of New South Wales

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Transcranial electrical stimulation (TES) techniques offer a novel treatment approach for depression and have shown promising efficacy. However, there is no published data to date on their effectiveness as a maintenance treatment. This study will investigate ways of using TES as a maintenance treatment to prevent relapse in depression.
